title: Jack Lennox
text:
John Patrick 'Jack' Lennox (21 March 1907 – 7 December 1943) was an Australian <a href="WWII">WWII</a> serviceman and prisoner of war. He had played <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20premiership">New South Wales premiership competition</a> with <a href="St.%20George%20Dragons">St. George</a> and <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney</a> in the 1930s.
Background.
Lennox was born in <a href="Mudgee%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Mudgee, New South Wales</a> on 21 March 1907.
Career.
Lennox came to <a href="St%20George%20Dragons">St George</a> in 1930 and played three seasons between 1930 and 1932. He played in the <a href="1930%20NSWRFL%20season">1930 Grand Final</a> for St. George in his debut year. He moved on to <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney</a> for <a href="1933%20NSWRFL%20season">season 1933</a> & <a href="1934%20NSWRFL%20season">1934</a>, before retiring from rugby league.
War service and death.
Jack Lennox enlisted in the <a href="Australian%20Army">Australian Army</a> in 1941 to fight in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. He was a gunner in the <a href="2/15th%20Field%20Regiment%20%28Australia%29">2/15th Field Regiment (Australia)</a>. The 2/15th regiment defended Singapore in 1941, were pushed back to the city and were captured by Japanese forces at the <a href="Fall%20of%20Singapore">Fall of Singapore</a>. Jack Lennox was made a prisoner of war of the Japanese, and died in a prison camp on 7 December 1943. He is listed on the Roll of Honor in his home town of <a href="Mudgee%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Mudgee, New South Wales</a>.
